Chicago, Illinois, United States | instrument = [[Drum]]s | genre = [[Chicago blues]] | occupation = [[Drummer]] | years_active = Late 1940s–1989 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Odie Payne''' (August 27, 1926 – March 1, 1989){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html |title=The 1980s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[drummer]]. Over his long career Payne worked with a range of [[musician]]s including [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]], [[Muddy Waters]], [[Jimmy Rogers]], [[Eddie Taylor]], [[Little Johnny Jones (pianist)|Little Johnny Jones]], [[Tampa Red]], [[Otis Rush]], [[Yank Rachell]], [[Sleepy John Estes]], [[Little Brother Montgomery]], [[Memphis Minnie]], [[Magic Sam]], [[Chuck Berry]], and [[Buddy Guy]]. ==Biography== He was born '''Odie Payne Jr.''' in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. Payne was interested in music from an early age, and did not restrict himself to a narrow musical genre. He studied music in [[high school]] and later [[military draft|drafted]] into the [[United States Army|Army]], but upon his [[military discharge|discharge]], Payne graduated from the Roy C. Knapp School of Percussion. By 1949 Payne was playing along with the [[pianist]] [[Little Johnny Jones (pianist)|Little Johnny Jones]], before meeting [[Tampa Red]] and enlisting into his band. The association lasted for around three years before, in 1952, Payne and Jones joined [[Elmore James]]'s band, the Broomdusters. Payne played with the Broomdusters for another three years, although his [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] association with them lasted through to 1959. In total he recorded thirty one [[single (music)|singles]] with them, including "[[The Sky Is Crying (song)|The Sky Is Crying]]". By this time Payne had become a favored [[session musician]] appearing through that decade on the [[Cobra Records|Cobra]] [[record label|label]], with [[Otis Rush]], [[Magic Sam]], and [[Buddy Guy]]. His playing also can be heard on various [[Chess Records|Chess]] [[Gramophone record|records]], including the [[Chuck Berry]] [[hit single]]s "[[Nadine (song)|Nadine]]", "[[You Never Can Tell (song)|You Never Can Tell]]", "[[Promised Land (song)|Promised Land]]" and 1964's "[[No Particular Place to Go]]." All appeared on the Berry's 1982 [[compilation album]], ''[[The Great Twenty-Eight]]''. Noted for his usage of the [[Cowbell (instrument)|cowbell]], [[bass drum pedal]], and extended [[cymbal]] and [[drum roll]]s, Payne's double shuffle drumming technique was much copied and utilised by both [[Fred Below]] and Sam Lay.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p110910/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Odie Payne |author=Erlewine, Michael|publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=May 27, 2010}} The technique called for Payne to use both his hands to effect the shuffle effect.{{cite web|url=http://www.drummerworld.com/Drumclinic/danielglassdoubleshuffle.html|title=Great Grooves from the History of R&B: "No Particular Place to Go" - Chuck Berry|author=Glass, Daniel|publisher=Drummerworld.com|accessdate=May 27, 2010}} Payne appears to have a [[songwriter|songwriting]] credit to his name for the song "Say Man," which was recorded by both [[Bo Diddley]] and [[Willie Mabon]]; although Payne's name certainly did not appear on every version published.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/odie-payne-jr-mn0000399343/songs |title=Odie Payne, Jr. | Songs |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}}{{cite web|author=Mark Deming |url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/say-man-mt0020113839 |title=Say Man - Bo Diddley | Listen, Appearances, Song Review |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} Odie Payne died in Chicago in March 1989, at the age of 62. ==See also== *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.google.co.uk/imgres?imgurl=http://www.earwigmusic.com/Images/payne.jpg&imgrefurl=http://www.earwigmusic.com/payne.shtml&usg=__NudbR8Z71KkG40RoYS_pIoRYvHo=&h=328&w=434&sz=41&hl=en&start=1&um=1&itbs=1&tbnid=ZAjWE2zbCvPVMM:&tbnh=95&tbnw=126&prev=/images%3Fq%3D%2522Odie%2BPayne%2522%26um%3D1%26hl%3Den%26sa%3DX%26rlz%3D1W1RNTN_en%26tbs%3Disch:1 Payne images at Earwigmusic.com] {{Authority control|VIAF=34644235}} {{Persondata | NAME = Payne, Odie | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[drummer]] | DATE OF BIRTH = August 27, 1926 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = March 1, 1989 | PLACE OF DEATH = Chicago, Illinois, United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Payne, Odie}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:1989 deaths]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American drummers]] [[Category:American session musicians]] [[Category:Blues drummers]] [[Category:Rhythm and blues drummers]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Chicago, Illinois]]
